author: Jared Diamond
title: The Baseball Season When Strikeouts Overtook Hits
text:
Five decades ago, in the now infamous summer of 1968, baseball faced a serious problem: Nobody could score.
St. Louis Cardinals legend Bob Gibson posted a 1.12 ERA, still a record for the live-ball era, which began in 1920. Hitters reached base less than 30% of the time, a level of ineptitude that harkened back to the 19th Century. Teams finished with a combined .237 batting average, the lowest in history, resulting in just 3.42 runs a game.
